Description: Body sherd of Chian, possibly Grand Style, pottery phiale mesomphalos; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with traces of tongue pattern in added white above undetermined motif in white and added red; narrow black band on top of rim; exterior: paired hook maeander frieze between narrow bands above trace of whirligig.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos interprets the exterior decoration as possibly part of a feline's legs. However, the feline would, in this case, be upside down and partly obscured by the underside of the phiale. The sherd is upside-down in her catalogue. Lemos also places this sherd in the Chalice Style. The whirligig pattern is found on a few Grand Style chalices. The interior decoration is unclear but is not a floral motif. Figurative motifs on the interior surface of Chian vases are found only in the Grand Style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 306, no. 1229, pl. 160)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1939) (phase 2)
